facts.text: Petitioner was a former Portuguese citizen who became a citizen of India after acquisition of Portuguese territories by Government of India on December 20, 1961.
Petitioner resident in Daman obtained 23 licences for import of goods worth over one million pounds between October 9 and December 4, 1961.
Licences valid for 180 days from issue and could be renewed.
Petitioner placed firm orders with foreign suppliers prior to December 20, 1961 for full value and made advance payments of over 3,88,000 pounds, with balance over 7,62,000 pounds to pay.
Goods under licences to be shipped in first quarter of 1962.
Goods did not arrive within 180 days; petitioner applied for extensions on various dates, refused.
Petitioner tried to persuade foreign suppliers to cancel orders and remit money, but refused.
Petitioner applied to Government of India to permit imports against licences, refused.
Petition filed in May 1963.
Portuguese territories acquired by India after military action (conquest).
Military Governor issued proclamation on December 30, 1961 allowing exports by sea per prior law; imports of goods already at sea with foreign exchange paid.
Chief Civil Administrator letter dated January 11, 1962 to President, Goa Chamber of Commerce: consider individual cases on merits with evidence of firm commitment before December 18, 1961.
Goa, Daman and Diu Administration Ordinance No. 11 of 1961 promulgated March 5, 1962: laws in force before December 20, 1961 continue until amended/repealed.
Goa, Daman and Diu Administration Act No. 1 of 1962 promulgated March 27, 1962 effective March 5, 1962: similar continuance of prior laws.

Goa, Daman and Diu Laws Regulation No. XII of 1962 effective November 22, 1962: enforced Indian laws including Imports and Exports Control Act 18 of 1947, repealed corresponding prior laws; s.4(2) preserves rights/privileges under repealed laws.
Order April 2, 1962: imports allowed if letters of credit opened by Dec 18, 1961 or goods shipped before Dec 20, 1961.
Order April 11, 1962: all imported goods require valid import licence.
Petitioner's case not covered by proclamation Dec 30, 1961, letter Jan 11, 1962, or order April 2, 1962.
Respondent contends licences issued not by Governor of Daman.
Emergency in force, Art. 19 suspended per Art. 358.

legal_issues.text: Whether refusal to permit imports under pre-acquisition licences violates Art. 19(1)(f) and (g).
Whether refusal amounts to discrimination under Art. 14.
Whether Government of India as new sovereign recognised rights under pre-December 20, 1961 import licences issued by former Portuguese Government.
Effect of conquest on obligations of new sovereign to honour commitments of former sovereign.

petitioner_arguments.text: Refusal to permit imports violates fundamental right under Art. 19(1)(f) and (g).
Government allowed imports to other similarly situated merchants, amounting to discrimination under Art. 14.
Government of India bound to allow imports as it recognised rights under pre-1961 licences.
Ordinance No.11/1961, Act No.1/1962, and Regulation XII/1962 continued old laws and preserved rights under licences.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.4(2) of Regulation XII/1962; State of Rajasthan v. Shyamlal

respondent_arguments.text: Art. 19 suspended due to emergency under Art. 358.
No discrimination; imports permitted to others not similarly circumstanced.
Licences not proved issued by Governor of Daman; not valid.
Licences expired after 180 days; no obligation to extend.
Territories acquired by conquest; new sovereign not bound to honour former sovereign's commitments unless recognised.
No recognition of petitioner's licences per proclamations and orders.

court_reasoning.text: In cases of acquisition by conquest, residents have only rights granted or recognised by new sovereign as between subjects and sovereign.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Undisputed position of law affirmed in precedents.

court_reasoning.text: Assumes licences valid but examines if Government of India recognised rights post-Dec 20, 1961.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proclamation Dec 30, 1961 recognised only imports of goods at sea with payment; petitioner's case not covered.

court_reasoning.text: Letter Jan 11, 1962 considered cases on merits for pre-Dec 18 commitments; petitioner's case not covered.
court_reasoning.key_observation: New sovereign not recognising all licences.

court_reasoning.text: Ordinance and Act continued old laws from March 5, 1962 but does not imply recognition of liabilities against new sovereign without explicit undertaking like in Shyamlal case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proclamation shows limited recognition; no Covenant provision assuming liabilities.

court_reasoning.text: Interregnum Dec 20, 1961 to March 5, 1962: old laws not necessarily continued as between sovereign and subjects; validated actions per ss.7 Ordinance/s.9 Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proclamation Dec 30 valid and limits recognition.

court_reasoning.text: Orders April 2 and 11, 1962 not covering petitioner's case; require licences.
Regulation XII s.4(2) preserves rights under repealed laws from March 5, 1962; licences pre-date.
Petitioner failed to prove discrimination under Art. 14.

holdings.text: New sovereign upon conquest not bound to honour former sovereign's commitments unless recognised; no recognition here for petitioner's licences.
Continuance of old laws does not imply assumption of liabilities without explicit recognition.

precedents_cited.relevance: Continuance of old laws may imply recognition if supported by covenant assuming liabilities; no such covenant here.

precedents_cited.case_name: M/s Dalmia Dadri Cement Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: In conquest/cession, subjects have only rights recognised by new sovereign.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Gujarat v. Vora Fiddali Badruddin Mithibarwala
precedents_cited.relevance: Cession is act of State; new sovereign recognises rights or not.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis of petition; Art. 19 suspended; no violation of Arts. 14/19 as no recognition.

statutes_cited.name: Goa, Daman and Diu Administration Ordinance No. 11 of 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Continued prior laws from March 5, 1962; validated interregnum actions.

statutes_cited.name: Goa, Daman and Diu Administration Act No. 1 of 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Continued prior laws from March 5, 1962; validated interregnum actions.

statutes_cited.name: Goa, Daman and Diu Laws Regulation No. XII of 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed prior import/export laws, enforced Indian Imports Act; preserved prior rights from enforcement date but not applicable.

statutes_cited.name: Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Enforced in territories via Regulation XII.

outcome.summary: Writ petition dismissed as new sovereign (Government of India) did not recognise rights under petitioner's pre-acquisition import licences issued by former Portuguese Government; no violation of Arts. 14 or 19.

key_quotes.text: "In such a case the residents of the territories did not carry with them the rights which they possessed as subjects of the ex-sovereign, and that as subjects of the new sovereign they had only such rights as are granted or recognised by him".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle on conquest and recognition of rights.

key_quotes.text: "the new sovereign did not recognise imports on the basis of licences like those granted to the petitioner, unless two conditions were fulfilled".
key_quotes.speaker: court
